---
  title: Aesthetics!
---




<div id="aesthetic-attributes" class="section level1">
<h1>Aesthetic Attributes</h1>
<p>We have focused on the data up until this point and now we will look at the aesthetic attributes. These consist of:</p>
<ul>
<li>Color</li>
<li>size</li>
<li>shape</li>
</ul>
<div id="color" class="section level2">
<h2>Color</h2>
<p>To start we will focus on the color. We will look at</p>
<ol style="list-style-type: decimal">
<li>Color by groups.</li>
<li>Color of points.</li>
</ol>
<div id="color-by-groups" class="section level3">
<h3>Color by Groups</h3>
<p>An important way to distinguish data can be to change the color of the groups. `ggplot2`` has many default scales that convert your groups to color levels. These can be over ridden but we will stick to the basics for now. We consider the same plot that we used before and now we will add color by the carrier brand:</p>
<pre class="r"><code>library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(nycflights13)
data = flights %&gt;% sample_frac(.01)

ggplot(data, aes(x=distance, y= dep_delay, color=carrier)) +
      geom_point()</code></pre>
<p>The code shows that in the aesthetic portion (<code>aes()</code>) and we have added that <code>carrier</code> is associated with color. The plot is shown below.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="color-of-points" class="section level3">
<h3>Color of points</h3>
<p>Not only can we add color to the aesthetic portion but we can add it into the particular layers.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(nycflights13)
data = flights %&gt;% sample_frac(.01)

ggplot(data, aes(x=distance, y= dep_delay)) +
      geom_point(color=blue)</code></pre>
<p>This will change the color of all the points as you can see below.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
</div>
<div id="size" class="section level2">
<h2>Size</h2>
<p>Now that we can color the points and color by groups we can also add the attributes of different sizes.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(nycflights13)
data = flights %&gt;% sample_frac(.005)

ggplot(data, aes(x=distance, y= dep_delay, size=air_time)) +
      geom_point()</code></pre>
<p>Note that whenever you see an attribute inside the <code>aes()</code> function it applies that attribute to a particular variable. In this case, the size of the points will be increased depending on the air time of the flight.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
</div>
<div id="shape" class="section level2">
<h2>Shape</h2>
<p>One other important attribute to distinguish between groups can be to have a unique shape for each group. This time we add <code>shape=carrier</code> into the <code>aes()</code> function and have a unique shape for each specific carrier.</p>
<pre class="r"><code>library(dplyr)
library(ggplot2)
library(nycflights13)
data = flights %&gt;% sample_frac(.01)

ggplot(data, aes(x=distance, y= dep_delay, shape = carrier)) +
      geom_point()</code></pre>
<p>This produces the graph that you see below.</p>
<p><img src="data:image/png;base64," width="672" /></p>
<p>Conclusion</p>
<ul>
<li>In each case we can group by size, shape or color.</li>
<li>We can also specify size, shape or color of a particular layer.</li>
</ul>
</div>
</div>




</div>
